reason.tex:
%text If $A$ is a square matrix (equal rows and columns), $A^{-1}$ is its inverse and $I$ is the Identity matrix then, % \begin{align} {\bf A\times A^{-1}=I} \end{align} \\
%text If you know how to compute the Adjoint of a matrix, then finding inverse is easy, % \begin{align} A^{-1}=\dfrac{1}{|A|}\cdot Adj(A) \\ \end{align} \\
%text The analysis behind it is, %
\begin{align} \text{}&|A|\cdot I=A\cdot Adj(A) \\ \implies & I=A \left(\dfrac{1}{|A|}Adj(A)\right) \\ \implies & A\cdot A^{-1}=A \left(\dfrac{1}{|A|}Adj(A)\right) \\ \implies & A^{-1}=\dfrac{1}{|A|}Adj(A) \end{align}
